Award.AwardTitle: Integrated Framework for 3D Analysis of Soil-Pile Interaction

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding for a theoretical and experimental study of soil-pile interaction problems. The fundamentals of a framework for the analysis of piles subjected to combined loading, based on insights into the mathematical form of the displacement field around the pile, calculus of variations and energy principles, will be developed. A series of load tests will be performed on half-section instrumented model piles installed in a half- circular chamber containing a plexiglass boundary along its diameter. The displacement field in the soil around model piles will be studied during the installation and loading stages using the Digital Image Correlation (DIC)technique. The model pile-soil interface behavior will be captured by both image analysis and conventional sensors. These experiments will provide data that will be useful in the establishment of the general mathematical form of the displacement field around loaded piles. Validation of the general theoretical framework will be done by comparison with results of a number of load tests on instrumented model piles.

The proposed work will help bridge knowledge gaps that currently exist in the understanding of the soil-pile interaction process. The framework for 3D soil-pile interaction analysis and the results of the experiments will establish the basis for accounting for the effects of soil layering and spatial heterogeneity of soil properties on pile resistance, which will allow future development of theories that will enable engineers to quickly analyze problems that at present can only be analyzed with very costly and time-intensive 3D FEA. The availability of an analysis that can take into account spatial variability in the ground will be useful in a variety of applications, including the assessment of the need to retrofit existing structures and the effectiveness of ground engineering interventions to mitigate seismic risks. This will be particularly useful as the United States works on retrofitting and building new infrastructure, which requires both the assessment of existing and design of new pile foundations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objectives of this project were i) the development of the infrastructure for performing experiments in which probes are pushed into and model piles are loaded in sand samples prepared in a large-scale, axisymmetric, half-cylindrical chamber and ii) the development of advanced 3D pile-soil interaction analyses.

The response of piles to structural loading strongly depends upon the method of installation and soil-pile interaction effects. In addition to the type of loading considered, the complex nature of the boundary-value problem itself, the effects of pile installation, and the nature of the soil (a particulate material with strongly nonlinear mechanical response) all contribute to the challenges of solving this problem. The project developed a new experimental methodology for understanding and quantifying the displacements in the soil and the deformation of the soil around piles subjected to loading and also around probes pressed into the soil and pushed through it.  A new half-circular calibration chamber has been fabricated with a transparent Plexigass observation window, through which it is now possible to acquire images of the pile or probe and the surrounding soil during the test. The Digital Image Correlation (DIC) technique has enabled the Purdue research team to determined the strain and displacement fields for each test.

Tests with a cone penetrometer (a cylindrical probe with a conical tip) were also performed in both uniform and multilayered sand samples in order to study the influence of the layer interface on cone penetration resistance. The effect of strong and weak layers on penetrometer-soil interface behavior has been captured by both image analyses and conventional sensors. Experiments have also included a series of load tests performed on half-section instrumented model piles pre-installed in the soil samples.

These experiments provided invaluable data that can be used in the validation of models and theoretical solutions for problems involving probe penetration in soil and pile loading that will result in the development of better, more effective design methods for pile foundations and more effective methods to interpret site characterization tests, such as the cone penetration test. Progress in this area is helpful in design and construction activities in connection with the development and maintenance of infrastructure in the United States.
